awd_titl_txt: Waste Infrastructure, Urban Citizenship, and the Process of Urban Planning
awd_abstract_narration:
Globalizing cities around the world face a myriad of challenges surrounding economic development, infrastructural upgrades, and the management of public space. Urban planners often confront competing interests of different constituent groups in their efforts to balance the need to modernize infrastructures with fostering of employment for the urban poor. Conversions of garbage dumps to modern sanitary landfills, for example, may reduce hazards to public health at the same time they threaten the livelihoods of thousands of people who rely on waste picking and recycling for survival. The contestations that take place over the right to the dump cut to the heart of urban citizenship and the poor's rights to the city and public space. This project will investigate how various stakeholder groups differently understand and value waste infrastructures and evaluate the labor implications of upgrades to sanitation facilities. In so doing, it will advance understanding of the infrastructure planning process, urban citizenship, and the means through which the urban poor contest projects that threaten their livelihoods. Research results will have valuable implications for planners, policymakers, and social justice advocates addressing the challenges posed by infrastructure modernization in cities of the Global South.  
 
This project focuses on a case study of a planned sanitation upgrade that has spawned an organized protest movement by waste pickers in Dakar, Senegal. Dakar is an ideal setting for this research because of its long history of peaceful, multi-party democracy, its long tradition of urban citizenship movements, and recent trends to "clean up" undesirable places and informal laborers. Dakar's sprawling dump, Mbeubeuss, is one of the oldest and largest landfills in Africa.  Though the government plan to upgrade the infrastructure has been frustrated over the last few years by protests, under pressure from its funder the World Bank, efforts are underway to push the upgrade forward in the next two years.  Through ethnographic research with key stakeholders, including government planners and waste pickers, the research will examine the planning process during this time as a window into material struggles around urban citizenship and the rights of the city's poorest. Extensive interviews, participant observation, and participatory mapping will be conducted in order to reveal the different spatial and material relations represented by the two infrastructures, how actors' contested visions for the dump are embedded in their material practices (e.g. recycling processes versus office work), and the forms of expert and vernacular knowledge marshaled by each group.  Special attention will be paid to the way that picker activists contest the authoritative knowledge of planning through their alternative development discourses and practices of civic science.  Contributing to debates in political infrastructures, geographies of waste, urban political ecology, and the politics of environmental knowledge, the research will show the material basis of urban citizenship and lend insight into strategies for more pro-poor infrastructure planning.

por.por_cntn:
Shuttering open air waste dumps is a key approach being taken by cities across the global South seeking to modernize infrastructure and clean up what are seen as antiquated, polluting spaces. However, a growing number of urban residents in developing countries forge their livelihoods through waste picking. As the production of waste expands exponentially in the Anthropocene, the reliance of the global poor on recycling is intensifying. Although waste picking provides employment for the city's most marginalized, drives vibrant recycling economies, and provides environmental services through reducing waste and reclaiming valuable materials, it is often stigmatized and waste pickers are treated as disposable.  Attempts to close these spaces are intensely fraught as waste pickers fight back for their rights to what they consider to be a waste commons.

This ethnographic research project examined the impending closure of Dakar?s municipal waste dump, Mbeubeuss, as a lens into debates around the politics of infrastructure, discard economies in the Anthropocene, and the cultural politics of urban development and planning in Africa. One of the largest open air dumps in Africa, Mbeubeuss provides employment for an estimated 2000 citizens and hosts a vast recycling economy that stretches well beyond Dakar.  A World Bank funded upgrade project now underway seeks to "valorize" the dump through eventually capping it and transitioning waste pickers to work in sorting factories and non-recycling sectors.  Dakar waste pickers are involved in a delicate struggle to defend their rights to the recycling economies they have built over the last 50 years.  In contesting the approach taken, waste pickers join with a chorus of waste pickers across the world organizing for more pro-poor strategies to modernize the wastescape.

The first element of the research was centered on depicting the lifeworlds on Mbeubeuss that have evolved since the dump's founding in 1968 and which are now threatened with erasure.  Through over 180 interviews with waste pickers and several months of participant observation with communities on Mbeubeuss and in its outskirts since 2016, the research characterizes the intricate salvage economies through which these workers return the city's detritus to circuits of value through their craft, expertise, and toil.  The built form of the dump is revealed as only the scaffolding within which a whole infrastructural ecology of embodied labour, community systems, spirits, faith, and inner worlds of garbage unfolds.  This is contrasted with the vision of the dump put forward by city planners and the dump's technicians who seek to modernize what is seen as a backwards and devoid of value.

A second key element of the research is tracking the first few years of the upgrade project, including the production of impact analyses, stakeholder consultation, and most recently, the impact of new policies and infrastructures breaking ground on the dump.   Through in depth interviews with government officials, dump technicians and planners, as well as close engagement with scholars, advocates, the waste pickers' association leadership, and local community leaders, the project traces the contestation surrounding the upgrade and its preliminary impacts on recyclers and community residents.  Special attention is paid to women waste pickers, especially the minority Christian women involved in food waste collection for pork production, and the particular challenges they face with the transformation of the dump.  

The results provide discard studies, critical infrastructure studies, Anthropocene studies, and urban studies literatures with a fine-grained investigation of the contours of life and value in the urban wastescape and the complexities of battles to modernize the city at the expense of the laboring poor.   

Outcomes of the project include academic presentations and publications, training of research personnel, and public dissemination. Publication of results in academic forums is ongoing. So far, one book chapter and one journal article has been produced and a book manuscript is in preparation. Moreover, a documentary film about the battle over the future of Mbeubeuss is currently in postproduction, produced in collaboration with the waste pickers and an advocacy NGO partner. These works are based on numerous academic conference presentations across a range of relevant fields, including geography, anthropology, discard studies, infrastructure studies, and African studies. Presentations were also given at a number of academic departments in the US, Canada, and Africa. One MA student was recruited through the project and completed an award winning dissertation about Mbeubeuss.  She benefited from training in a wide range of geographical research techniques, analysis, and presentation. One researcher in Dakar benefitted from a range of training in ethnography, translation, and film production.  Public dissemination of project findings has included podcast and news media interviews.
